The TARDBP (TAR DNA-binding protein) gene encodes TDP-43, a RNA-binding protein involved in RNA processing and stress granule dynamics. Mutations in TARDBP are a well-established cause of frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). In FTLD, TDP-43 pathology is a major hallmark, often presenting with behavioral changes and language deficits. In ALS, TDP-43 mislocalization and aggregation contribute to motor neuron degeneration. TDP-43 pathology is also observed in some cases of Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. The pathway includes components of complex I, suggesting a link between mitochondrial dysfunction and neurodegeneration. The biological effect of TARDBP mutations is the disruption of RNA metabolism and protein homeostasis, leading to neuronal loss. This primarily contributes to \boxed{Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)}.

Mutations in TARDBP are strongly associated with frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Activated AKT inhibits BAD, a pro-apoptotic protein, thereby promoting cell survival and proliferation. Mutations in NRAS, such as gain-of-function mutations, lead to constitutive activation of this pathway, driving uncontrolled cell growth and resistance to apoptosis. The APRT (adenine phosphoribosyltransferase) gene is involved in the purine salvage pathway, catalyzing the conversion of adenine to inosine monophosphate (IMP). Mutations in APRT can lead to a deficiency in this enzyme, resulting in the accumulation of adenine and its metabolites, which are toxic to cells. This accumulation primarily affects the kidneys, leading to the formation of adenine nucleotide crystals and subsequent kidney damage. The most common disease associated with APRT deficiency is Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by neurological abnormalities, self-injurious behavior, and hyperuricemia. However, in cases where only one copy of the APRT gene is mutated (heterozygous state), the condition may manifest as a milder form of hyperuricemia and kidney stones. The specific biological effect of the APRT allele is therefore central to the pathogenesis of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and related metabolic disorders. \boxed{Lesch-Nyhan syndrome}

The SOD1 allele is implicated in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). SOD1, or superoxide dismutase 1, is an enzyme that normally detoxifies superoxide radicals. Mutations in SOD1 lead to the production of toxic protein aggregates, which contribute to motor neuron degeneration. The pathway described involves the ubiquitin-proteasome system, where SOD1 is ubiquitinated and directed to the proteasome for degradation. Dysfunction in this pathway, including impaired proteasomal degradation of misfolded SOD1, results in protein accumulation and neurotoxicity. This process is central to the pathogenesis of ALS. The ABL1 gene encodes a non-receptor tyrosine kinase that plays a critical role in the BCR-ABL fusion protein, which is a hallmark of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The BCR-ABL fusion results from a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the Philadelphia chromosome. This fusion protein exhibits constitutive tyrosine kinase activity, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation and survival by activating downstream signaling pathways, including the RAS-MAPK pathway. This aberrant signaling promotes leukemic transformation and resistance to apoptosis. The ABL1 allele, when fused to BCR, drives the transformation of hematopoietic cells, contributing directly to the development of CML. \boxed{Chronic Myeloid Leukemia}

This phosphorylation inactivates RB1, releasing it from its inhibitory effect on E2F transcription factors. The NAGS gene encodes N-acetylglutamate synthase, an enzyme critical for the urea cycle. This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of glutamate to N-acetylglutamate, a key activator of carbamoyl-phosphate synthase 1 (CPS1), which initiates the urea cycle. Mutations in NAGS lead to reduced CPS1 activity, impairing the conversion of ammonia to urea. This results in hyperammonemia, a buildup of ammonia in the blood, which is toxic to the brain. This condition is known as N-acetylglutamate synthetase deficiency, a rare autosomal recessive disorder. Affected individuals may present with neurological symptoms such as seizures, ataxia, and developmental delay. The disease is part of the broader urea cycle disorders. \boxed{N-acetylglutamate synthetase deficiency}

The thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme plays a critical role in thyroid hormone synthesis by catalyzing the iodination of tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin (TG), forming monoiodo- (MIT) and diiodo- (DIT) tyrosine residues. These residues then couple to form triiodothyronine (T3) and tetraiodothyronine (T4). Mutations in the TPO gene impair this process, leading to reduced thyroid hormone production. This dysfunction contributes to autoimmune thyroid disease, specifically **Hashimoto's thyroiditis**, an inflammatory condition where the immune system attacks the thyroid gland. The defective TPO function also increases the risk of **thyroid hormone resistance** and **hypothyroidism**. These effects are linked to genetic predisposition and immune-mediated mechanisms, making TPO a key gene in thyroid autoimmunity. \boxed{Hashimoto's thyroiditis}

The NAGS gene encodes N-acetylglutamate synthase, an enzyme critical for the urea cycle. This enzyme catalyzes the formation of N-acetylglutamate from acetyl-CoA and glutamate, which is a key activator of CPS1, carbamoyl-phosphate synthase 1. Mutations in NAGS lead to reduced N-acetylglutamate production, impairing CPS1 activity and disrupting the urea cycle. This results in the accumulation of ammonia, leading to neurological toxicity. The specific disease associated with NAGS mutations is **hyperammonemia**, a condition characterized by elevated blood ammonia levels. This can cause encephalopathy, seizures, and coma. NAGS deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder, primarily affecting infants and leading to severe neurological complications if untreated. \boxed{Hyperammonemia}
